PM 26557432
DT Article
TI Spider crabs of the Western Atlantic with special reference to fossil
   and some modern Mithracidae.
AU Klompmaker, Adiel A. (adielklompmaker@gmail.com) 
   Portell, Roger W.
   Klier, Aaron T.
   Prueter, Vanessa
   Tucker, Alyssa L.
SO PeerJ
VL 3
PS e1301
PD Oct 1 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Spider crabs (Majoidea) are well-known from modern oceans and are also
   common in the western part of the Atlantic Ocean. When spider crabs
   appeared in the Western Atlantic in deep time, and when they became
   diverse, hinges on their fossil record. By reviewing their fossil
   record, we show that (1) spider crabs first appeared in the Western
   Atlantic in the Late Cretaceous, (2) they became common since the
   Miocene, and (3) most species and genera are found in the Caribbean
   region from the Miocene onwards. Furthermore, taxonomic work on some
   modern and fossil Mithracidae, a family that might have originated in
   the Western Atlantic, was conducted. Specifically, Maguimithrax gen.
   nov. is erected to accommodate the extant species Damithrax
   spinosissimus, while Damithrax cf. pleuracanthus is recognized for the
   first time from the fossil record (late Pliocene[long dash]early
   Pleistocene, Florida, USA). Furthermore, two new species are described
   from the lower Miocene coral-associated limestones of Jamaica (Mithrax
   arawakum sp. nov. and Nemausa windsorae sp. nov.). Spurred by a recent
   revision of the subfamily, two known species from the same deposits are
   refigured and transferred to new genera: Mithrax donovani to Nemausa,
   and Mithrax unguis to Damithrax. The diverse assemblage of decapods from
   these coral-associated limestones underlines the importance of reefs for
   the abundance and diversity of decapods in deep time. Finally, we
   quantitatively show that these crabs possess allometric growth in that
   length/width ratios drop as specimens grow, a factor that is not always
   taken into account while describing and comparing among taxa.
C1 Klompmaker, Adiel A.; Univ Florida, Florida Museum Nat Hist, 1659 Museum
   Rd, Gainesville, FL, 32611, USA, USA.
EM adielklompmaker@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 2167-8359

   zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America; USA; Central
   America; West Indies; Marine zones; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Neogene
DE Damithrax cf. pleuracanthus [Florida /  / first fossil record]
   [Caenozoic / Plio-Pleistocene / ].

DT Article
TI NEW ARCHAEOCYATHS FROM THE SLEEPING GIANTS RIDGE COMPLEX, EASTERN
   ALABAMA.
AU McMenamin, Mark A.S.
SO Southeastern Geology
VL 51
IS 3
PS 129-134
PD Oct 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lower Cambrian strata (Weisner-Shady Formations) of the Sleeping Giants
   Ridge Complex in eastern Alabama have produced archaeocyaths not
   previously reported from the southern Appalachians. The unusual,
   thorny-archaeocyath Yukonensis sp. is reported here and represents the
   first find of the genus outside of Yukon Territory and Alaska. An Early
   Cambrian archaeocyath with taeniae belonging to Suborder Archaeocyathina
   also occurs at Sleeping Giants. The occurrence of Yukonensis sp. in
   Alabama is in accord with the concept of faunal interchange between the
   archaeocyath faunas of (present day coordinates) eastern and western
   North America.
C1 McMenamin, Mark A.S.; Mt Holyoke Coll, Dept Geol & Geog, S Hadley, MA,
   01075, USA, USA.

SN 0038-3678

   [Cambrian / Lower Cambrian / ].

DT Article
TI Late Ordovician and early Silurian brachiopods from the Zagros Ranges,
   Iran.
AU Ghavidel-Syooki, Mohammad (m_ghavidelsyooki@yahoo.com) 
   Popov, Leonid E.
   Pour, Mansoureh Ghobadi
   Alvaro, J. Javier
   Ehsani, Mohammad H.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 105
IS 3
PS 159-187
PD Oct 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 5
AB Brachiopods are among the most common components of the Late Ordovician
   benthic faunal assemblages recorded in the Faraghan Mountains, Zagros
   Ranges, Iran. A total of 19 species referable to 16 genera are
   identified, including seven new species; namely Drabovia elegans,
   Hibernodonta bonehensis, Hedstroemina zakeenensis, Jezercia faraghani,
   Protomendacella multicostata, Tafilaltia dargazensis and Tafilaltia
   seyahouensis. Reported brachiopod assemblages are oligotaxic (2-3
   species per assemblage) to monotaxic. The only exception is the medium
   diversity Aegiromena-Hedstroemina Association, with up to ten species,
   which occurs at the lower part of the A. nigerica Zone. Low diversity
   patterns were probably controlled by the palaeogeographical position of
   the region in high southern latitudes throughout the Ordovician.
   Paterula sp. and Iranospirifer sp. are the only brachiopods documented
   from the Silurian (Llandovery) Sarchahan Formation. This paper gives the
   first detailed report of shelly fossils from the Llandovery 'hot shale'
   of the Arabian margin of Gondwana. Most of the Katian genera, and many
   of their species, are shared with neighbouring high- to mid-latitude
   peri-Gondwanan margins, including Morocco, Spain, France, Sardinia and
   Bohemia.

   Ghobadi/0000-0001-9594-6074; Popov, Leonid/0000-0003-1710-2612

DT Article
TI A new haplolepid fauna (Osteichthyes: Actinopterygii) from the Lower
   Coal Measures of Scotland: Westphalian A; Langsettian, Carbonicola
   communis chronozone (Bashkirian).
AU Elliott, Francis M.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 105
IS 3
PS 207-225
PD Oct 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Seven new species and one new genus of the family Haplolepidae
   (Actinopterygii: Palaeonisciformes) are described from new material
   obtained from the Drumgray coal shales, North Lanarkshire: Westphalian A
   (Bashkirian): Protohaplolepis isabellae; Protohaplolepis limnades;
   Protohaplolepis traquairi; Parahaplolepis alexandrae; Parahaplolepis
   elenae; Pyritocephalus youngii and Millerolepis eleionomae. The
   discovery of these new taxa increases the number of haplolepid species
   found in Europe to 16, thus producing a faunal count more than
   comparable to that of North America. This high concentration of
   haplolepid remains in limnic deposits is also a strong indication that
   these fish were not only adapted to a coastal paralic basin, but also
   well-adapted to a freshwater brackish environment. A comprehensive
   description of the skull roof morphology, including a short description
   of some of the larger dermal bones, is given of seven new haplolepid
   species obtained from the coal shale tips at Wester Bracco and Shotts in
   North Lanarkshire. In consequence, a revised table of the
   stratigraphical distribution of the Haplolepidae in Europe is provided.
   Furthermore, the new genus Millerolepis is assigned to the subfamily
   Parahaplolepinae and the generic position of the problematic Haplolepis
   attheyi from Newsham, Northumberland is discussed, with the taxonomic
   position of Protohaplolepis proposed.
C1 Elliott, Francis M.; SUERC, Rankine Ave,Scottish Enterprise Technol Pk,
   E Kilbride, Lanark, G75 0QF, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Evolution;
   Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; United
   Kingdom; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Haplolepidae [Skull / Skull characters / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Fossil
   assemblages /  / Systematics] [Europe /  / geographical &
   stratigraphical distribution] [Scotland / Lanarkshire, north / ]
   [Carboniferous /  / ] [ / Bashkirian / ]. 
   Millerolepis [Carboniferous /  / New genus].

DT Article
TI A new species of Alpaida (Araneae, Araneidae) from Southeastern Brazil.
AU Castanheira, Pedro de S. (pedrocastanheira.bio@gmail.com) 
   Baptista, Renner L.C.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 105
IS 3
PS 372-375
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Alpaida venger sp.nov. is described based on males and females from
   Pedra Branca State Park, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. This species seems to
   be related to Alpaida scriba (Mello-Leitao, 1940) and Alpaida alticeps
   (Keyserling, 1879) due to similar body shape and color, but is easily
   distinguished by the very elongated median apophysis, the massive lobe
   of tegulum and the hooked paracymbium of male palp. Females have
   elongated epigyne as A. scriba, but can be distinguished by the wider
   lips and shorter scape.
C1 Castanheira, Pedro de S.; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Lab Diversidade
   Aracnideos, Ave Carlos Chagas Filho 373, Rio De Janeiro, BR-21941902 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM pedrocastanheira.bio@gmail.com
OI Castanheira, Pedro/0000-0002-0623-1622; Cerqueira Baptista, Renner
   Luiz/0000-0002-2372-5034
SC Zoology
SN 0073-4721
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Alpaida venger [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Alpaida venger (Araneae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 372].

DT Article
TI Centrodraco fidelis (Draconettidae), a new deepwater dragonet species
   from the southern Loyalty Ridge, southwestern Pacific Ocean.
AU Fricke, Ronald (ronfricke@web.de) 
SO Cybium
VL 39
IS 3
PS 211-217
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Centrodraco fidelis sp. nov. is described from three specimens, which
   were collected on the southern Loyalty Ridge (New Caledonian EEZ) during
   the oceanographic cruise EXBODI. The species is characterised by: 14
   rays in the second dorsal fin; 13 rays in the anal fin; first dorsal fin
   with the second spine elongate and filamentous in the male; second
   dorsal fin very low, without filaments in the male; opercular spine
   1.8-2.4 in subopercular spine; body slightly compressed; body depth
   7.4-8.5% of SL; body width 7.7-8.8% of SL; pectoral fin short, not
   reaching to anus when adpressed; pectoral fin length 9.9-11.8% of SL;
   male body colour pattern pale, with a single grey spot on the beginning
   of the lower lateral line; filament in first dorsal fin pale, fin with a
   large basal dark blotch; the male anal fin with three dark blotches. The
   new species is compared with allied species. A revised key to the genera
   and species of Draconettidae presented.
C1 Fricke, Ronald; Ramstal 76, Lauda Konigshofen, D-97922, Germany,
   Germany.
EM ronfricke@web.de
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Centrodraco fidelis [South Pacific / Loyalty Islands / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Draconettidae
OR Draconettidae (Perciformes): [Key to genera, P. 215; Key to species, P.
   215]. 
   Centrodraco fidelis (Draconettidae): [Sp nov, Loyalty Islands (marine),
   P. 212].

DT Article
TI A new Stiphodon (Gobiidae) from Indonesia.
AU Keith, Philippe (keith@mnhn.fr) 
   Busson, Frederic
   Sauri, Sopian
   Hubert, Nicolas
   Hadiaty, Renny
SO Cybium
VL 39
IS 3
PS 219-225
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of Stiphodon, an amphidromous goby, is described from
   streams of three islands in Indonesia, Java, Bali and Lombok. It differs
   from other species of the genus by a combination of characters including
   14-15 pectoral rays, a second dorsal fin with nine segmented rays, fewer
   scales in predorsal, transverse forward and transverse back series, and
   a diagnostic golden and black pattern in male.
C1 Keith, Philippe; Museum Natl Hist Nat, UMR 7208, CP 026,43,Rue Cuvier,
   Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM keith@mnhn.fr
OI Hubert, Nicolas/0000-0001-9248-3377

   region; Eurasia; Asia

   Perciformes, Gobiidae

   Premaxillary teeth & scale counts, p. 222].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201001414
DT Article
TI Newly Boomed Mite Pest of Papaya in Taiwan.
AU Ho, Chyi-Chen
   Wang, Shun-Cheng (scwang1@cyut.edu.tw) 
   Huang, Shih-Ying
   Shih, Hsien-Tzun
SO Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
VL 64
IS 3
PS 239-241
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eutetranychus africanus (Tucker) population of very high density was
   found to be the key pest in three screen-housed-papaya orchards in
   Gaoshu, Pintung County. Panonychus citri (McGregor) and Tetranychus sp.
   may occur simultaneously in much smaller population. This is the second
   time that Eu. africanus was reported as crop pest in Taiwan and the
   first time to be a key pest. More information is needed to understand
   the popularity of this mite in papaya orchards. The recognition of the
   different spider mite genera on papaya by the shape, habitat, and color
   was described concisely.
C1 Wang, Shun-Cheng; Chaoyang Univ Technol, Dept Environm Engn &
   Management, Taichung, Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM scwang1@cyut.edu.tw
SC Zoology; Agriculture; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
BD Animals and man; Damage caused by animals; Damage to vegetation;
   Ecology; Population dynamics; Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Eutetranychus africanus [Damage to crops / Pest status / new record]
   [Population density /  / ] [Cultivated land habitat / Papaya orchards /
   ] [Taiwan /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Eutetranychus africanus (Acari): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201001414
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006592
DT Article
TI Changes of the systematic positions of eight species and two subgenera
   of the genus Holotrichia (Scarabaeidae, Melolonthinae, Melolonthini).
AU Matsumoto, Takeshi
SO Kogane
VL 17
PS 5-10
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Systematic positions of eight species and two subgenera of Holotrichia
   are changed. The following eight species are transferred from the genus
   Holotrichia to Chaetocosmetes Moser: Holotrichia cuniculus, H. mus, H
   bilobiceps, H. chondropyga, H felina, H capella, H platypyga and H
   acutangula, and morphological characters of Chaetocosmetes are
   described. Ancylonycha nigra Redtenbacher, on which Eretusa, a subgenus
   of Holotrichia, was established, is synonymized with Sophrops
   planicollis Burmeister, and Holotrichia standfitssi Brenske, the type
   species of Noanda is transferred to the genus Sophrops. Thus, Eretusa
   and Noanda are synonymized with the genus Sophrops.
C1 Matsumoto, Takeshi; Nishi Miyahara 2-6-20-102,Yodogawa Ku, Osaka,
   5320004, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1346-0943
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type species; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae

   Chaetocosmetes javanus Moser 1917, p. 6].

   Transferred from Holotrichia, p. 8]. 
   Chaetocosmetes bilobiceps - (Arrow 1944) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Holotrichia, p. 6]. 
   Chaetocosmetes capellus - (Arrow 1938) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Holotrichia, p. 8]. 
   Chaetocosmetes chondropygus - (Arrow 1938) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Holotrichia, p. 8]. 
   Chaetocosmetes cuniculus - (Arrow 1938) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Holotrichia, p. 6]. 
   Chaetocosmetes felinus - (Arrow 1938) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Holotrichia, p. 8]. 
   Chaetocosmetes javanus - Moser 1917 (Scarabaeidae): [Designated type
   species for, Chaetocosmetes Moser 1917, p. 6]. 
   Chaetocosmetes mus - (Arrow 1938) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Holotrichia, p. 6]. 
   Chaetocosmetes platypygus - (Arrow 1938) (Scarabaeidae): [Comb nov,

DT Article
TI Separation of Amphitrichia from Holotrichia (Scarabaeidae,
   Melolonthinae, Melolonthini) with description of a new species and new
   records of two known species.
AU Matsumoto, Takeshi
SO Kogane
VL 17
PS 11-17
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Amphitrichia, formerly treated as a subgenus of Holotrichia, is given a
   generic rank and redescribed. Thirty seven species are transferred from
   Holotrichia to Amphitrichia and a new species is described from southern
   Sulawesi under the name of A. gracilicalcarata. Amphitrichia
   flaviventris (Lansberge) is newly recorded from Lombok Is., Flores Is.,
   Sulawesi Is. and Yamdena Is. of Tanimbar Isis., and A. constricta
   (Burmeister) is also newly recorded from Bali Is., Indonesia.
C1 Matsumoto, Takeshi; Nishi Miyahara 2-6-20-102,Yodogawa Ku, Osaka,
   5320004, Japan, Japan.

   Taxonomic position; Status; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006594
DT Article
TI Taxonomic notes on the genus Eotrichia Medvedev (Scarabaeidae,
   Melolonthinae, Melolonthini).
AU Matsumoto, Takeshi
SO Kogane
VL 17
PS 19-24
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eotrichia, which was originally established as an independent genus but
   has been treated as one of the subgenera of the genus Holotrichia, is
   regarded as an independent genus again and is redescribed on the basis
   of the redefined characters. Forty-six species are assigned to the genus
   Eotrichia and are listed. hi addition, Holotrichia titanis Reitter,
   1902, the type species of the genus Eotrichia, is synonymized with
   Eotrichia niponensis (Lewis, 1895).
C1 Matsumoto, Takeshi; Nishi Miyahara 2-6-20-102,Yodogawa Ku, Osaka,
   5320004, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1346-0943
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Status
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae

   from, Holotrichia (Eotrichia), p. 19].

DT Article
TI Notes on the genus Apogonia (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Melolonthinae)
   from Thailand collected by Drs. K. Masumoto & K. Takahashi.
AU Kobayashi, Hirokazu
SO Kogane
VL 17
PS 53-72
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twenty eight species of the genus Apogonia collected by Drs. K. Masumoto
   and K. Takahashi from Thailand are studied and listed. Among them, 8
   species are new to science and 9 species are newly recorded from
   Thailand, and 3 species are unidentified. New species are described
   under the names of Apogonia protracta sp. nov., A. takahashii sp. nov.,
   A. paracribricollis sp. nov., A. masumotoi sp. nov., A. sombooni sp.
   nov., A. communis sp. nov., A. sinuolata sp. nov. and A.
   castanetferorata sp. nov.
C1 Kobayashi, Hirokazu; Kamishakujii Minamicho 3-16,Nerima Ku, Tokyo,
   1770043, Japan, Japan.

   Eurasia; Asia

AU Masumoto, Kimio

VL 17
PS 91-100
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New taxa of the genus Nothochodaeus from North and Northeast Thailand
   are dealt with. Two new species and one new subspecies are described:
   Nothochodaeus angkhaiensis sp. nov., N. phakluaimaiensis sp. nov., and
   N. sakaii khaoyaiensis ssp. nov. A key to all the species and subspecies
   of the genus Nothochodaeus from North and Northeast Thailand is also
   provided.

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Aegus from Penang Island, West Malaysia.
AU Araya, Kunio
   Fujita, Kazuhisa
SO Kogane
VL 17
PS 123-126
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Aegus (Coleoptera, Lucanidae) is described
   from Penang Island, West Malaysia under the name of Aegus rhomboidodon
   sp.nov. This new species resembles Aegus coomani Dither, 1926 originally
   described from Vietnam in general external morphology, but both male and
   female of the former are easily distinguishable from those of the latter
   by the several characteristics including mandibular teeth.
C1 Araya, Kunio; Kyushu Univ, Fac Social & Cultural Studies, Motooka 744,
   Fukuoka, 8190395, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology

   Eurasia; Asia

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006607
DT Article
TI Studies on Leptaulax anibarbis Kuwert (Coleoptera, Passalidae) and its
   related species.
AU Johki, Yutaka
   Araya, Kunio
   Kon, Masahiro
SO Kogane
VL 17
PS 131-141
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Leptaulax anibarbis, which has been synonymized with L. papua, is
   regarded as a valid species by comparing the lectotypes of L. papua and
   L. anibarbis, both of which are redescribed based on the lectotypes. In
   addition, a new Leptaulax species, which appears closely related to L.
   anibarbis, is described from Mt. Trus Madi, Sabah, Borneo, under the
   name of L. sawaii sp. nov. Furthermore, two known species closely
   resembling L. anibarbis, L. barbicauda and L. sarcrwakus, are studied.
   It is confirmed that L. barbicauda is closely related to L. anibarbis
   but distinct from the latter, and the male genitalia of L. barbicauda
   are described for the first time. For L. sarawakus, the population from
   Sabah, Borneo is described as a new subspecies, L. sarcrwakus kashizakii
   ssp. nov.
C1 Johki, Yutaka; Showa Womens Univ, Grad Sch Human Life Sci, Tokyo,
   1548533, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1346-0943
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Leptaulax sarawakus kashizakii [Malaysia /  / New subspecies]. 
   Leptaulax sawaii [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Passalidae
OR Leptaulax anibarbis - Kuwert 1898 (Passalidae): [Redescription,
   Lectotype, p. 132; Removal from synonymy, With Leptaulax papua Kuwert
   1898, p. 133]. 
   Leptaulax barbicauda - (Zang 1905) (Passalidae): [First time described,
   Male genitalia, p. 138]. 
   Leptaulax papua - Kuwert 1898 (Passalidae): [Redescription, Lectotype,
   p. 133; Removal from synonymy, Leptaulax anibarbis Kuwert 1898, p. 133].
   
   Leptaulax sarawakus kashizakii (Passalidae): [Subsp nov, Malaysia, P.
   139]. 
   Leptaulax sawaii (Passalidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 135]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201006607
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006901
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Neodermation Fain (Acariformes:
   Dermationidae) and the first record of the precopulatory mate-guarding
   among dermationids.
AU Bochkov, Andre V. (andrevbochkov@gmail.com) 
   Mironov, Sergey V.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 20
IS 6
PS 612-628
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new species Neodermation actitis sp. nov. (Acariformes: Dermationidae)
   is described from the Common Sandpiper Actitis hypoleucos (Linnaeus)
   (Charadriiformes: Scolopacidae) in the Russian Far East using light and
   scanning electron microscopy. The new species differs from the closely
   related Neodermation belonopteri Fain, 1964 in the following features:
   in males, the hysteronotal shield is distinctly ornamented (vs.
   unornamented in N. belanopteri), setae e2 are situated on the
   hysteronotal shield (vs. off this shield), the external projection of
   the terminal membrane is triangular and subequal to the median one (vs.
   smaller than the median projection); in females, the posterolateral
   projections of the hysteronotal shield are strongly sclerotized (vs.
   sclerotized as other parts of this shield. An emended diagnosis of the
   genus Neodermation is given. Differences in the external morphology of
   male and female tritonymphs of N. actitis are also described.
   Precopulatory mate-guarding behavior is recorded for the first time for
   dermationids.
C1 Bochkov, Andre V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Embankment 1,
   St Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM andrevbochkov@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Reproductive Biology
SN 1362-1971
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Reproduction; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia
DE Actitis hypoleucos [Arachnid parasites / Neodermation actitis / New
   parasite species] [Russia /  / New arachnid parasite species]. 
   Dermationidae [Reproductive behaviour / Precopulatory mate-guarding
   behaviour / First report]. 
   Neodermation actitis [Avian hosts / Actitis hypoleucos / New parasite
   species] [Russia /  / New species from avian host]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Birds; Chelicerates; Chordates; Invertebrates;
   Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves,
   Charadriiformes, Scolopacidae
OR Dermationidae (Acari). 
   Neodermation - Fain 1964 (Acari): [Emended diagnosis, P. 613]. 
   Neodermation actitis (Acari): [Sp nov, Russia, Parasite of Actitis
   hypoleucos (Aves), p. 614; Parasite]. 
   Actitis hypoleucos (Scolopacidae): [Host]. 
DI 10.11158/saa.20.6.4
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201006901
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006902
DT Article
TI New species and records of mites of the superfamily Oripodoidea (Acari,
   Oribatida) from Brazil.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Tolstikov, Andrei V.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 20
IS 6
PS 629-640
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB An annotated checklist of the Brazilian Oripodoidea is provided. It
   includes 14 species from eight genera and three families. Four species,
   Protoribates paracapucinus, Peloribates perreti, Scheloribates
   (Bischeloribates) elegantulus and Haplozetes minutus, are recorded for
   the first time in Brazil; of these, the last species is recorded for the
   first time in the Neotropical region. Two new species of the family
   Haplozetidae are described and illustrated on the basis of adult
   specimens. Protoribates lemensis sp. nov. differs from all
   representatives of the triaunguis-group by the presence of prolamellar
   lines and notogastral setae of medium size. Haplozetes biheterodactylus
   sp. nov. is most similar to H. minimicoma Beck, 1964, however, it
   differs from the latter by the long interlamellar setae and bidactylous
   legs.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
RI Tolstikov, Andrey/B-2119-2013
OI Tolstikov, Andrey/0000-0002-8537-038X

SN 1362-1971
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Haplozetes biheterodactylus; Protoribates lemensis [Brazil /  / New
   species]. 
   Haplozetes minutus [Neotropical region /  / New record] [Brazil /  / ]. 
   Oripodoidea [Checklists / Annotated checklist / ] [Brazil /  / ]. 
   Peloribates perreti; Protoribates paracapucinus; Scheloribates
   (Bischeloribates) elegantulus [Brazil /  / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Haplozetes biheterodactylus (Acari): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 636]. 
   Haplozetes minutus (Acari): [New record]. 
   Oripodoidea (Acari). 
   Peloribates perreti (Acari): [New record]. 
   Protoribates lemensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 631]. 
   Protoribates paracapucinus (Acari): [New record]. 
   Scheloribates (Bischeloribates) elegantulus (Acari): [New record].

DT Article
TI Three new species and two new records of the family Microtrombidiidae
   (Acari: Prostigmata) from Iran.
AU Noei, Javad (noei.javad@birjand.ac.ir) 
   Saboori, Alireza
   Hajizadeh, Jalil
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 20
IS 6
PS 655-673
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Atractothrombium amirkabiri sp. nov., Ettmuelleria zahediae sp. nov. and
   Microtrombidium fumani sp. nov. of the subfamily Microtrombidiinae Thor,
   1935 are described from Guilan province, northern Iran. Moreover,
   Enemothrombium culicoidium (Vercammen-Grandjean and Cochrane, 1974) of
   the subfamily Valgothrombiinae Gabrys, 1999 and Empitrombium makolae
   Sevsay & Karakurt, 2013 of the Microtrombidiidae incertae sedis are
   reported for the first time from Iran. All species were collected from
   soil samples (off host) in a forest.

PT J
AN ZOOR15201006907
DT Article
TI New species and new records of mites of the genus Stigmaeus (Acari:
   Prostigmata: Stigmaeidae) from Western Siberia with redescription of S.
   livschitzi Kuznetsov, 1977.
AU Khaustov, Alexander A. (alex1973khaustov@gmail.com) 
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 20
IS 6
PS 681-692
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of the genus Stigmaeus Koch, 1836 (Acari: Stigmaeidae), S.
   tolstikovi sp. nov. is described from rotten log of poplar from Western
   Siberia, Russia. Stigmaeus delaramae Khanjani, 2014 is recorded for the
   first time from Russia. Stigmaeus livschitzi Kuznetsov, 1977, S.
   longipilis (Canestrini, 1889), S. sphagneti (Hull, 1918), S.
   purpurascens Summers, 1962, and S. silvestris Khaustov, 2014 are
   recorded for the first time in Asian part of Russia. Stigmaeus
   livschitzi is redescribed based on study of type material. The key to
   species of the genus Stigmaeus of Russia is provided.
C1 Khaustov, Alexander A.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM alex1973khaustov@gmail.com
RI Khaustov, Alexander/S-1303-2016
OI Khaustov, Alexander/0000-0002-0306-112X
SC Zoology
SN 1362-1971
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Stigmaeus [Russia /  / Key to species]. 
   Stigmaeus delaramae [Russia /  / New record]. 
   Stigmaeus livschitzi; Stigmaeus longipilis; Stigmaeus purpurascens;

   record].

TI A new snout mite, Spinibdella tabarii sp nov (Trombidiformes: Bdellidae)

AB Spinibdella tabarii Paktinat-Saeej & Bagheri sp. nov. is described and
   illustrated from Amol city, Mazandaran province, Iran. Worldwide
   distributions and differential characters of all Spinibdella are

DT Article
TI A new species of Scissuralaelaps (Acari: Mesostigmata: Laelapidae) from
   millipedes in the Philippines.
AU Seeman, Owen D. (owen.seeman@qm.qld.gov.au) 
   Alberti, Gerd
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 20
IS 6
PS 707-720
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of Scissuralaelaps (Acari: Laelapidae: Iphiopsidinae), S.
   huberi sp. nov., is described from the millipede Acladocricus sp.
   (Spirobolida: Rhinocricidae) in the Philippines. The new species is
   close to S. bipartitus Ishikawa, which also has males with heavily
   sclerotised anterior and lateral margins of the peritrematal and
   metapodal shields.

   Australia, Australia.

   Parasites; Hosts; Myriapod hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia;
   Asia

   species] [Philippines /  / New arachnid parasite species]. 
   Scissuralaelaps huberi [Diplopod hosts / Acladocricus / New parasite
   species] [Philippines /  / New species from arthropod host].

DT Article
TI A taxonomic revision of the genus Oxyopomyrmex Andre, 1881 (Hymenoptera:
   Formicidae).
AU Salata, Sebastian (rubisco198@gmail.com) 
   Borowiec, Lech
SO Zootaxa
VL 4025
IS 1
PS 1-66
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Oxyopomyrmex Andre, 1881 is a small genus of myrmicine ants found in
   arid grasslands of the Mediterranean region. Here we provide a new
   taxonomic revision of the genus. Twelve species are recognized,
   including five new to science: O. laevibus sp. nov. (Greece: Crete), O.
   magnus sp. nov. (Spain), O. negevensis sp. nov. (Israel) O. polybotesi
   sp. nov. (Greece: Nisyros, W Turkey) and O. pygmalioni sp. nov.
   (Cyprus). Oxyopomyrmex santschii var. nigripes Santschi, 1907 and O.
   santschii var. nitidior Santschi, 1910 are raised to species level. The
   following new synonymies are proposed: O. krueperi Forel, 1911 = O.
   lagoi Menozzi, 1936 syn. nov.; O. nigripes Santschi, 1907 = O. sabulonis
   var. rugocciput Santschi, 1923 syn. nov. = O. emeryi var. brunnescens
   Santschi, 1929 syn. nov.; O. nitidior Santschi, 1910 = O. emeryivar.
   laticeps Santschi, 1915 syn. nov. = O. emeryi st. sabulonis Santschi,
   1915 syn. nov.; O. saulcyi Emery, 1889 = O. santschii Forel, 1904 syn.
   nov. = O. santschii var. siciliana Karavaiev, 1912 syn. nov. = O.
   gaetulus Santschi, 1929 syn. nov. = O. saulcyi var. latinodis Santschi,
   1939 syn. nov. A neotype for O. oculatus Andre, 1881 is designated. An
   identification key based on the gyne, male and worker caste is provided.
C1 Salata, Sebastian; Univ Wroclaw, Dept Biodivers & Evolutionary Taxon,
   Przybyszewskiego 63-77, Wroclaw, PL-51148, Poland, Poland.
EM rubisco198@gmail.com
RI Salata, Sebastian/X-1140-2019
OI Salata, Sebastian/0000-0003-0811-2309; Borowiec,
   Lech/0000-0001-5668-6855
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; Key; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe;
   Greece
DE Oxyopomyrmex [Checklists /  / Systematic review] [Africa / Mediterranean
   region / ] [Eurasia /  / ]. 
   Oxyopomyrmex laevibus [Crete /  / New species]. 
   Oxyopomyrmex magnus [Spain /  / New species].

   Formicoidea, Formicidae

   var. rugocciput Santschi 1923, p. 34; Raised from, Oxyopomyrmex

   [Lectotype designated, P. 40; Raised to, Oxyopomyrmex nitidior, p. 40].

   latinodis Santschi 1939, p. 55].

DT Article
TI A review of the mite subfamily Harpirhynchinae (Acariformes:
   Harpirhynchidae) - parasites of New World birds (Aves: Neognathae).
AU Bochkov, Andre V. (andrevbochkov@gmail.com) 
   OConnor, Barry M.
   Klompen, Hans
SO Zootaxa
VL 4023
IS 1
PS 1-130
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 32
AB Mites of the subfamily Harpirhynchinae (Acariformes: Cheyletoidea:
   Harpirhynchidae) associated with neognathous birds (Aves: Neognathae) in
   the New World are revised. In all, 68 species in 8 genera are recorded.
   Among them, 27 new species and 1 new genus are described as new for
   science: Harpyrhynchoides gallowayi Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp.
   nov. from Columba livia (Columbiformes: Columbidae) from Canada
   (Manitoba), H. zenaida Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from
   Zenaida macroura (Columbiformes: Columbidae) from USA (Michigan), H.
   calidris Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Calidris minutilla
   (Charadriiformes: Scolopacidae) from USA (Kansas), H. actitisBochkov,
   OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Actitis macularius (Charadriiformes:
   Scolopacidae) from Canada (British Columbia), H. charadrius Bochkov,
   OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Charadrius vociferus (Charadriiformes:
   Charadriidae) from USA (Texas), H. pluvialis Bochkov, OConnor and
   Klompen sp. nov. from Pluvialis dominica (Charadriiformes: Charadriidae)
   from USA (Ohio), H. bubulcus Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from
   Bubulcus ibis (Pelecaniformes: Ardeidae) from USA (Florida), H.
   ixobrychus Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Ixobrychus exilis
   (Pelecaniformes: Ardeidae) from USA (Michigan), H. puffinus Mertins sp.
   nov. from Puffinus gravis (Procellariformes: Procellariidae) from USA
   (Florida), H. megascops Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from
   Megascops asio (Strigiformes: Strigidae) from USA (Michigan), H. athene
   Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Athene canicularia
   (Strigiformes: Strigidae) from USA (Texas), H. coccyzus Bochkov, OConnor
   and Klompen sp. nov. from Coccyzus americanus (Cuculiformes: Cuculidae)
   from USA (Michigan), H. crotophaga Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov.
   from Crotophaga ani (Cuculiformes: Cuculidae) from Suriname; Crassacarus
   Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen, gen. nov.: Crassacarus alexfaini Bochkov,
   OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. (type of genus) from Cardinalis cardinalis
   (type host) from USA (Michigan), Passerina ciris (unknown locality in
   North America) (Passeriformes: Cardinalidae), and Setophaga petechia
   (Passeriformes: Parulidae) from USA (Michigan), C. tinae Bochkov,
   OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Carduelis tristis (Passeriformes:
   Fringillidae) from USA (Wyoming), C. fritschi Bochkov, OConnor and
   Klompen sp. nov. from Bombycilla cedrorum (Passeriformes: Bombycillidae)
   from USA (Michigan), C. sialia Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov.
   from Sialia currucoides (Passeriformes: Turdidae) from USA (Wyoming), C.
   melanerpesBochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Melanerpes
   formicivorus (Piciformes: Picidae) from USA (Kansas); Neharpyrhynchus
   turdus Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Turdus migratorius
   (Passeriformes: Turdidae) from USA (Michigan), N. campylorhynchus
   Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Campylorhynchus
   brunneicapillus (Passeriformes: Troglodytidae) from USA (unknown
   locality), N. spizella Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from
   Spizella passerina (Passeriformes: Emberizidae) from USA (various
   localities), N. quiscalus Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from
   Quiscalus quiscula (Passeriformes: Icteridae) from USA (Michigan), N.
   agelaius Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from Agelaius phoeniceus
   (Passeriformes: Icteridae) from USA (Michigan), N. bombycilla Bochkov,
   OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. Bombycilla cedrorum (Passeriformes:
   Bombycillidae) from USA (Michigan), N. vireo Bochkov, OConnor and
   Klompen sp. nov. from Vireo olivaceus (Passeriformes: Vireonidae) from
   USA (Florida), N. picidarum Bochkov, OConnor and Klompen sp. nov. from
   Colaptes auratus (type host), Melanerpes formicivorus, Melanerpes
   uropygidialis, and Picoides pubescens (Piciformes: Picidae) from USA
   (various localities); Perharpyrhynchus charadrius Bochkov, OConnor and
   Klompen sp. nov. from Charadrius vociferus (Charadriiformes:
   Charadriidae) from USA (Michigan). Harpyrhynchoides oenae lamorali
   (Fain, 1972) syn. nov. is synonymized with Harpyrhynchoides oenae (Fain,
   1972). Harpirhynchoides agapornis (Fain, 1972) comb. nov. and
   Crassacarus cylindripalpus (Fritsch, 1954) comb. nov. are transferred
   from the subgenus Pseudoharpirhynchus Fain, Bochkov and Mironov, 1999
   (type species Harpirhynchus agapornis Fain, 1972) of the genus
   Harpirhynchus Megnin 1877. The subgenus Pseudoharpirhynchus syn. nov. is
   synonymized with the genus Harpyrhynchoides. Diagnoses for the subfamily
   and all genera recorded in the New Word (Anharpyrhynchus Fain, 1972,
   Crassacarus gen. nov., Harpirhynchus, Harpyrhynchoides Fain, 1972,
   Fainharpirhynchus Bochkov and Galloway, 2013, Neharpyrhynchus Fain,
   1972, Perharpyrhynchus Fain, 1972, Trichorhynchiella Fain, 1995) are
   provided. Keys to all harpirhynchine genera and all their species
   occurring in the New World are also given. A list of all harpirhynchine
   species and their hosts is compiled.

PT J
AN ZOOR15201002331
PM 26624160
DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of the genus Benthana Budde-Lund, 1908 (Isopoda:
   Oniscidea: Philosciidae).
AU Campos-Filho, Ivanklin Soares (ivanklin.filho@gmail.com) 
   Taiti, Stefano
   Araujo, Paula Beatriz
SO Zootaxa
VL 4022
IS 1
PS 1, 3-73
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The neotropical genus Benthana (Philosciidae) is reviewed. Fourteen
   species are redescribed: Benthana picta, B. olfersii, B. longicornis, B.
   schubarti, B. albomarginata, B. werneri, B. santosi, B. longipenis, B.
   bocainensis, B. moreirai, B. dimorpha, B. iporangensis, B. sulcata, and
   B. longicaudata. Additional characters were proposed for B. convexa, B.
   taeniata, B. serrana, B. trinodulata, B. araucariana, and B. cairensis.
   New records are provided for 13 species, and four new species are
   described: Benthana aimores sp. nov., Benthana goitacas sp. nov.,
   Benthana tupinamba sp. nov. and Benthana canastraensis sp. nov.. Two
   Chilean species are considered incertae sedis. A pictorial key and
   distribution maps for the species are provided.
C1 Campos-Filho, Ivanklin Soares; Univ Fed Rio Grande Sul, Programa Posgrad
   Biol Anim, Av Bento Goncalves 9500, Porto Alegre, RS, BR-91501970 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM ivanklin.filho@gmail.com

   Beatriz/A-2455-2008; Taiti, Stefano/O-2202-2019

   Beatriz/0000-0002-7587-3936;

   tupinamba [Brazil /  / New species].

   Peracarida, Isopoda

PT J
AN ZOOR15404024686
DT Article
TI A new large trapdoor spider species of the genus Heligmomerus Simon 1892
   (Araneae, Mygalomorphae, Idiopidae) from Western Ghats, India.
AU Sanap, Rajesh V.
   Mirza, Zeeshan A. (snakeszeeshan@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Biodiversity
VL 8
IS 3
PS 242-246
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of trapdoor spider, Heligmomerus maximus sp. nov. is
   described from southern Western Ghats of Kerala state, India. The new
   species differs from known species of the genus from India and Sri Lanka
   in possessing a band of thorn-like spinules on coxa IV. Moreover it is
   the largest species of the genus with adult females reaching a length up
   to 32 mm and the burrows are shallow compared with other species of the
   genus. Copyright (C) 2015, National Science Museum of Korea (NSMK) and
   Korea National Arboretum (KNA). Production and hosting by Elsevier.
C1 Mirza, Zeeshan A.; Tata Inst Fundamental Res, Natl Ctr Biol Sci,
   Bangalore, Karnataka, India, India.
EM snakeszeeshan@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 2287-884X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Heligmomerus maximus [Kerala /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Heligmomerus maximus (Araneae): [Sp nov, Kerala, P. 243]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15404024686
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

TI New species of Himalmartensus Wang & Zhu, 2008 (Araneae: Amaurobiidae)
   with the first description of a male from the Nanda Devi Biosphere
   Reserve, Western Himalaya, India.
AU Quasin, Shazia (shazia@wii.gov.in) 
   Siliwal, Manju
   Uniyal, Virendra Prasad
SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Biodiversity
VL 8
IS 3
PS 247-250
PD Sep 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Himalmartensus Wang & Zhu, 2008 (Family:
   Amaurobiidae) is described from Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve, Western
   Himalaya, India. In this study, a male specimen of this genus is
   described for the first time from India. Copyright (C) 2015, National
   Science Museum of Korea (NSMK) and Korea National Arboretum (KNA).
   Production and hosting by Elsevier.

PT J
AN ZOOR15201001736
DT Article
TI Actaea grimaldii, a new species of reef crab from Papua New Guinea
   (Crustacea, Brachyura, Xanthidae).
AU Ng, Peter K.L. (peterng@nus.edu.sg) 
   Bouchet, Philippe
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 140
PS 1-18
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of xanthid crab, Actaea grimaldii, is described from the
   coral reefs of Papua New Guinea. This species has a distinctive red and
   white coloration and is closest to Actaea spinosissima Borradaile, 1902,
   from the Indian Ocean. However, the new species can be distinguished by
   the arrangement of spines on the carapace, chelipeds and ambulatory
   legs, and the structure of the male gonopods. Actaea grimaldii sp. nov.
   has also been confused with A. polyacantha (Heller, 1861), but differs
   markedly in the carapace armature.
C1 Ng, Peter K.L.; Natl Univ Singapore, Lee Kong Chian Nat Hist Museum,
   Singapore, 119260, Singapore, Singapore.
EM peterng@nus.edu.sg
SC Zoology
SN 2118-9773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Actaea grimaldii [South Pacific / Indonesia / New species] [ / Papua New
   Guinea / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Actaea grimaldii (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea (marine), P. 3].
   
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201001736
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15201004162
DT Article
TI A hog-nosed shrew rat (Rodentia: Muridae) from Sulawesi Island,
   Indonesia.
AU Esselstyn, Jacob A. (esselstyn@lsu.edu) 
   Achmadi, Anang S.
   Handika, Heru
   Rowe, Kevin C.
SO Journal of Mammalogy
VL 96
IS 5
PS 895-907
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB We document a new genus and species of shrew rat from the north
   peninsula of Sulawesi Island, Indonesia. The new taxon is known only
   from the type locality at 1,600 m elevation on Mt. Dako, in the district
   of Tolitoli. It is distinguished from all other Indonesian murines by
   its large, flat, pink nose with forward-facing nares. Relative to other
   Sulawesi murines, the species has extremely large ears ([approximately]
   21% of head and body length), very long urogenital hairs, prominent and
   medially bowing hamular processes on the pterygoid bones, extremely long
   and procumbent lower incisors, and unusually long articular surfaces on
   the mandibular condyles. Morphologically, the new taxon is most similar
   to a group of endemic Sulawesi rats known commonly as "shrew rats."
   These are long faced, carnivorous murines, and include the genera
   Echiothrix, Melasmothrix, Paucidentomys, Sommeromys, and Tateomys. Our
   Bayesian and likelihood analyses of DNA sequences concatenated from 5
   unlinked loci infer the new shrew rat as sister to a clade consisting of
   Melasmothrix, Paucidentomys, and Echiothrix, suggesting that Sulawesi
   shrew rats represent a clade. The Sulawesi water rat, Waiomys mamasae,
   was sister to the shrew rats in our analyses. Discovery of this new
   genus and species brings known shrew rat diversity on Sulawesi to 6
   genera and 8 species. The extent of morphological diversity among these
   animals is remarkable considering the small number of species currently
   known.
C1 Esselstyn, Jacob A.; Louisiana State Univ, Museum Nat Sci, 119 Foster
   Hall, Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, USA, USA.
EM esselstyn@lsu.edu
OI Handika, Heru/0000-0002-2834-7175
SC Zoology
SN 0022-2372
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Hyorhinomys stuempkei [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae
OR Hyorhinomys (Muridae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Murinae, Type species
   Hyorhinomys stuempkei, p. 897]. 
   Hyorhinomys stuempkei (Muridae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 899].

DT Article
TI The genus Visiana Swinhoe (Lepidoptera: Geometridae: Larentiinae) in
   Australia: resurrection of two species from synonymy.
AU Schmidt, Olga (Olga.Schmidt@zsm.mwn.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 4
PS 501-514
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on the study of morphological characters and DNA barcode (CO1)
   data, the present review revealed the existence of at least three
   species of Visiana Swinhoe (Lepidoptera: Geometridae: Larentiinae) in
   Australia. Visiana brujata (Guenee) is redescribed, and two species V.
   incertata (Walker), stat. rev. and V. repentinata (Walker), stat. rev.
   are resurrected from synonymy with V. brujata. Visiana breviaria
   (Walker), syn. rev., previously cited as a synonym of V. brujata, is now
   considered a synonym of V. incertata. Visiana brujata and V. incertata
   show close affinities with the sordidata group of species, whereas V.
   repentinata belongs to the vinosa species group. Images of adults and
   genitalia of all types are illustrated and the presence of the gnathos
   in the genus Visiana is discussed.
C1 Schmidt, Olga; SNSB Zool Staatssammlung Munchen, Munchhausenstr 21,
   Munich, D-81247, Germany, Germany.
EM Olga.Schmidt@zsm.mwn.de

   Reproductive Biology; Genetics &Heredity

DT Article
TI Five new rotundabaloghiid mites (Acari: Uropodina) from South-East Asia.
AU Kontschan, Jeno (kontschan.jeno@agrar.mta.hu) 
   Kiss, Balazs
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 4
PS 515-528
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Five new species of the family Rotundabaloghiidae are described from
   Indonesia and Malaysia. Angulobaloghia pedunculata sp. nov. differs from
   the other Angulobaloghia Hirschmann, 1979 species in the shape of the
   genital shield of the female. Rotundabaloghia (Rotundabaloghia) wangi
   sp. nov. has one pair of short and pilose setae (V8) on the ventral
   idiosoma, which is unique in the subgenus Rotundabaloghia
   (Rotundabaloghia) Hirschmann, 1975. Rotundabaloghia (Circobaloghia)
   javaensis sp. nov. has a small triangular anterior process on genital
   shield of female, which has not been detected previously in South-East
   Asian members of this subgenus. The long and thick ventral seta (V4) in
   Depressorotunda (Depressorotunda) robusta sp. nov. is a character state
   so far unknown in the subgenus Depressorotunda (Depressorotunda)
   Kontschan, 2010. Depressorotunda (Depressorotunda) hirca sp. nov. has
   two apically serrate anterior branches on the margin of the female
   genital shield.

DT Article
TI Redescription of the Indo-West Pacific scorpionfish (Scorpaenidae),
   Neomerinthe erostris (Alcock 1896), a senior synonym of Scorpaena
   gibbifrons Fowler 1938, N. rotunda Chen 1981, and N. bathyperimensis
   Zajonz & Klausewitz 2002.
AU Motomura, Hiroyuki (motomura@kaum.kagoshima-u.ac.jp) 
   Causse, Romain
   Bearez, Philippe
   Mishra, Subhrendu Sekhar
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 4
PS 529-540
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Indo-West Pacific species, Neomerinthe erostris (Alcock 1896),
   originally described as Scorpaena erostris, is redescribed as a senior
   synonym of Scorpaena gibbifrons Fowler 1938, N. rotunda Chen 1981, and
   N. bathyperimensis Zajonz & Klausewitz 2002. Although the latter three
   nominal species have been regarded as valid species and N. erostris has
   not been reported since 1898, examinations of type specimens of the four
   nominal species revealed that they represent a single species. A
   lectotype of Scorpaena erostris is herein designated. Neomerinthe
   erostris is characterized by having a distinct longitudinal ridge on the
   lateral surface of the maxilla and a strongly rounded dorsal profile of
   the head.
C1 Motomura, Hiroyuki; Kagoshima Univ Museum, 1-21-30 Korimoto, Kagoshima,
   8900065, Japan, Japan.
EM motomura@kaum.kagoshima-u.ac.jp
RI Bearez, Philippe/D-2383-2012
OI Bearez, Philippe/0000-0003-0397-2393
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Synonymy
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Scorpaeniformes, Scorpaenidae
OR Neomerinthe erostris - (Alcock 1896) (Scorpaenidae): [Redescription, P.
   531; Syn nov, Neomerinthe bathyperimensis Zajonz & Klausewitz 2002, p.
   537; Syn nov, Neomerinthe rotunda Chen 1981, p. 536; Syn nov, Scorpaena
   gibbifrons Fowler 1938, p. 537]. 
   Scorpaena erostris - Alcock 1896 (Scorpaenidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 536].

VL 4021

AB Six species in the genus Busonia Distant are described and illustrated,
   including five new species from Thailand and Malaysia: Busonia curvata,
   B. fusca, B. lactata, B. micrata, B. serrata, spp. nov., and one newly
   recorded species from China: Busonia albilateralis Maldonado-Capriles. A
   redescription of this genus is provided together with a key to species
   for separation of males.

DT Article
TI Study of Gryllacridinae (Orthoptera: Stenopelmatidae) from Thailand and
   adjacent countries: the genera Ultragryllacris gen. nov and
   Capnogryllacris.
AU Gorochov, Andrej V. (orthopt@zin.ru) 
   Dawwrueng, Pattarawich
   Artchawakom, Taksin
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 4
PS 565-577
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new material on the genera Ultragryllacris gen. nov. and
   Capnogryllacris Karny, 1937 from Thailand, Laos and Cambodia is
   considered. Five new species and subspecies are described: U. pulchra
   sp. nov.; U. p. alboclypeata subsp. nov.; C. thaica sp. nov.; C.
   sakaerat sp. nov.; C. phaeocephala cambodiensis subsp. nov.
   Capnogryllacris s. l. is divided into two possible subgenera
   (Capnogryllacris s. str. and Dictyogryllacris Karny, 1937, stat. nov.)
   as a minimum; the former genera Borneogryllacris Karny, 1937, syn. nov.,
   Marthogryllacris Karny, 1937, syn. nov. and Erythrogryllacris Karny,
   1937, syn. nov. are treated as synonyms of the subgenus Capnogryllacris.
   Previously unknown female for C. khmerica Gorochov, 2003 is described;
   neotype for C. martha (Griffini, 1914), type species of
   Marthogryllacris, is designated; C. erythrocephala Gorochov, 2003, sp.
   ressur. and C. e. borealis Gorochov, 2003, stat. ressur. are restored
   from synonyms of C. martha and from species status, respectively.

TI Heliothrips haemorrhoidalis and its relatives, with one new species and
   one new genus (Thysanoptera: Thripidae).
AU Nakahara, Steve (Cheryle.A.ODonnell@aphis.usda.gov) 
   O'Donnell, Cheryle A.
   Mound, Laurence A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 4
PS 578-584
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Heliothrips similis sp.n. is described as a close relative of the
   greenhouse thrips, Heliothrips haemorrhoidalis. This is the third
   species recognized here in the Neotropical genus Heliothrips. A pest
   species described from South Africa as Heliothrips sylvanus is
   transferred to a new genus, Neoheliothrips gen.n., as Neoheliothrips
   sylvanus (Faure) comb.n.

DT Article
TI New species and records of Pseudacteon Coquillett, 1907 (Diptera,
   Phoridae), parasitoids of the fire ant Solenopsis geminata group
   (Hymenoptera, Formicidae).
AU Lavinscky Pereira, Thalles Platiny (thallesplp@gmail.com) 
   Charles Delabie, Jacques Hubert
   Bravo, Freddy
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 4
PS 585-590
PD Sep 29 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Pseudacteon Coquillett (Diptera, Phoridae) has a worldwide
   distribution and comprises parasitic myrmecophilous species that
   decapitate host ants. Seventy one species are known in the genus, 41 of
   them occur in the Neotropical Region and are 25 from Brazil. In
   northeastern Brazil, there are only records for two species, Pseudacteon
   dentiger Borgmeier and Pseudacteon antiguensis Malloch. In this paper,
   two new species of the genus are described from female specimens,
   Pseudacteon pesqueroi new spec. and Pseudacteon plowesi new spec., and
   also, new records of three Pseudacteon species for the Brazilian
   Northeast are given.
C1 Lavinscky Pereira, Thalles Platiny; Univ Sao Paulo, Inst Biociencias,
   Rua Matao,Travessa 14,101,Cidade Univ, Sao Paulo, SP, BR-05508900 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM thallesplp@gmail.com
OI Pereira, Thalles Platiny Lavinscky/0000-0003-2075-3643

   Solenopsis (Hymenoptera), p. 587; Parasite]. 
   Pseudacteon plowesi (Phoridae): [Sp nov, Brazil, Parasite of Solenopsis
   geminata (Hymenoptera), p. 588; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Studies on the Genus Boysidia Ancey from China, with Description of One
   New Species (Pulmonata: Stylommatophora: Pupillidae).
AU Fang, Fukang
   Wang, Junwang
   Chen, Yuanxiao (cyx616@hotmail.com) 
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 34
IS 5
PS 688-694
PD September 28 2015
PY 2015
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Boysidia Ancey, 1881 is a small group in Chondrininae and distributes in
   South and Southeast Asia. A total of 24 species were recorded in south
   Qinling Mountains, China. Among of these species, one was identified as
   a new record. Descriptions of this new species and other 8 species of
   Boysidia (Bensonenella) were given in the text. The type specimens of
   the new species were kept in Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of
   Sciences, and the Department of Cell Biology and Medical Genetics,
   Kunming Medical University. Key to subgenus of Boysidia (Boysidia),
   Boysidia (Bensonella), Boysidia (Paraboysidia) and Boysidia (Dasypupa)
   1. Columellar tooth with node-shaped on aperture deep, angular tooth and
   parietal tooth united into 2 crescent knife-shaped tooch......Boysidia
   (Dasypupa) Thompson and Dance, 1983 Columellar tooth without node-shaped
   on aperture deep......2 2. Columellar tooth oblique......3 Columellar
   tooth not oblique, horizontal......Boysidia (Paraboysidia) Pilsbry, 1917
   3. Angular tooth and parietal tooth united into 1 flake-shaped tooch,
   palatal tooth with hook-shaped......Boysidia (Bensonella) Pilsbry, 1900
   Angular tooth and parietal tooth independence,
   parallel......Boysidia(Boysidia)Pilsbry, 1917 Boysidia (Bensonella)
   qingliangfengensis sp. nov. (Fig. 1: A-E) Holotype: alt. 3.40 mm, diam.
   2.10 mm; alt. of aperture 1.15 mm, diam. of aperture 0.75 mm. Collected
   from Longtangshan town, Linan city, Qingliangfeng Nature Reserve
   (30[degree]01[minute]N, 118[degree]80[minute]E), June 26, 2013.
   Paratypes: 126 specimens. alt. 3.30-3.45 mm, diam. 2.00-2.20 mm; alt. of
   aperture 1.10-1.20 mm, diam. of aperture 0.700-0.815 mm. Collected from
   Longtangshan town, Linan city, Qingliangfeng Nature Reserve
   (30[degree]01[minute]N, 118[degree]80[minute]E), June 26, 2013.
   Etymology: The name of the new species was based on Longtangshan town,
   Linan city, Qingliangfeng Nature Reserve from where the specimens were
   collected. Shell small, thin, luster, elongatedly conic. 5(1/2) whorls,
   moderately convex, spire long, the body whorl inflated, the bottom of
   body whorl not extended to aperture, and not form a bell-shaped. Apex
   blunt, embryo-whorls (1-2(1/2)) increased slowly, smooth, striae absent.
   Suture deep. Shell yellow brown or pale yellow in colour. Aperture
   elliptical, aperture margin thick, slightly expanded and not reflexed,
   with 16 rib-strias on the neck of aperture. With 14 teeth in the
   aperture: 1 little nipple-formed infraparietal lamella, l large
   flake-formed parietal lamalla, 1 big flake-formed angular lamella, 1
   small nipple-formed twin-lamella, 2 small nipple-shaped parallel lamella
   on right aperture margin, 2 small nipple-shaped suprapalaral plicae on
   the parallel lamella down, 1 big nipple-shaped upper palatal plicae and
   1 small nipple-formed interpalatal plicae, 1 small nipple-shaped lower
   palatal plicae on aperture botton. 1 big nipple-formed basal plicae on
   the below part of columella margin nearly, 1 small nipple-shaped
   columellar lamella on the columella margin above, 1 small nipple-formed
   subcolumellar lamella on the columellar lamella down. Umbilicus big,
   with hole-formed, and the umbilicus was not covered by columella margin.
   Habitat: Boysidia (Bensonella) qingliangfengensis sp. nov., as other
   Boysidia (Bensonella) species, usually lives on limestone areas of
   mountainous regions, in dark, moist habitats with bryophyte and lichen,
   in the cracks of the rocks or under the faller leaves. This new species
   is bigger than Boysidia (Bensonella) plicidens (Benson, 1849), but
   differs obviously from the bigger size: the new species shell with
   whorls 5(1/2), alt. 3.40 mm, diam. 2.10 mm; alt. of aperture 1.15 mm,
   diam. of aperture 0.75 mm. Aperture elliptical, aperture margin thick,
   slightly expanded and not reflexed, with 16 rib-strias on the neck of
   aperture, with 14 teeth on the aperture: 1 little nipple-formed
   infraparietal lamella, l large flake-formed parietal lamalla, 1 big
   flake-formed angular lamella, 1 small nipple-formed twin-lamella, 2
   small nipple-shaped parallel lamella on right aperture margin, 2 small
   nipple-shaped suprapalaral plicae on the parallel lamella down, 1 big
   nipple-shaped upper palatal plicae and 1 small nipple-formed
   interpalatal plicae, 1 small nipple-shaped lower palatal plicae on
   aperture botton. 1 big nipple-formed basal plicae on the below part of
   columella margin, 1 small nipple-shaped columellar lamella on the
   columella margin above, 1 small nipple-formed subcolumellar lamella on
   the columellar lamella down. The latter with 5 whorls (alt. 2.00 mm,
   diam. 1.50) in small size, and the aperture irregular, subtriangular,
   having 9 folds teeth: 3 parietal lamellae, of which the upper two are
   long; one small dentiform columellar lamellae; five palatals, of which
   two subbasal plicae being minute. Basal margin has a callous outside.
   Umbilicus narrow.
C1 Chen, Yuanxiao; Department of Cell Biology and Medical Genetics, Kunming
   Medical University, Kunming 650500, China, China.

DT Article
TI Two new species, including one representing a new genus, of the West
   African millipede family Campodesmidae (Diplopoda: Polydesmida).
AU Vandenspiegel, D. (didier.van.den.spiegel@africamuseum.be) 
   Golovatch, S.I.
   Nzoko Fiemapong, A.R.
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 139
PS 1-11
PD Sep 28 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus, Campodesmoides gen. nov., is described to only encompass C.
   corniger sp. nov., from Cameroon. This genus and species is
   distinguished from the few known species of the small western African
   family Campodesmidae, all currently in Campodesmus, by the much longer
   antennae and legs, the normal pore formula with ozopores borne on
   porosteles, and the suberect and distally twisted gonopod, coupled with
   peculiar horns on a few anterior postcollum segments. A new Campodesmus
   is also described, C. alobatus sp. nov., from Ivory Coast, which differs
   from congeners primarily in the lack of a dorsal/lateral lobe on the
   otherwise usual and strongly subcircular gonopod telopodite, albeit the
   latter is not directed mesad, but held subparallel to the main body
   axis.
C1 Vandenspiegel, D.; Musee Royal Afrique Cent, Tervuren, B-3480, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM didier.van.den.spiegel@africamuseum.be
RI Golovatch, Sergei/J-7036-2018
SC Zoology
SN 2118-9773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa
DE Campodesmidae [Cameroon /  / New record]. 
   Campodesmoides corniger [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
   Campodesmus alobatus [Ivory Coast /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Diplopoda
OR Campodesmidae (Diplopoda): [New record]. 
   Campodesmoides (Diplopoda): [Gen nov, Of family Campodesmidae, Type
   species Campodesmoides corniger, p. 2]. 
   Campodesmoides corniger (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 2]. 
   Campodesmus alobatus (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Ivory Coast, P. 6].

DT Article
TI A new species of Spelaeogammarus (Amphipoda: Bogidielloidea: Artesiidae)
   with an identification key for the genus.
AU Bastos-Pereira, Rafaela (rafaelabastospereira@gmail.com) 
   Ferreira, Rodrigo L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 3
PS 418-432
PD Sep 28 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB There are five described species of the cave-dwelling amphipods of the
   genus Spelaeogammarus, all of them inhabiting caves on the Brazilian
   state of Bahia. A new species of this genus is here described, which is
   closely related to the already known species S. santanensis and S.
   titan. Spelaeogammarus sanctus sp. nov. differs from its congeneric
   species basically by the presence of more than 18 bifid setae on the
   dorsal margin of uropod 3 outer ramus and telson with one apical and two
   subapical stout setae, while the other species generally present less
   setae on the third uropod and more setae on telson. An identification
   key and an updated table of the Spelaeogammarus species diagnosis are
   provided, as well as a multivariate statistical approach of
   morphological variations among the species.
C1 Bastos-Pereira, Rafaela; Univ Fed Lavras UFLA, Ctr Estud Biol
   Subterranea, Lavras, MG, Brazil, Brazil.
EM rafaelabastospereira@gmail.com
RI Ferreira, RL/L-8419-2014
OI Ferreira, RL/0000-0003-3288-4405

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Description of a new Betylobraconini-like parasitoid wasp genus and
   species (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Rogadinae) from Chile.
AU Quicke, Donald L.J.
   Butcher, Buntika A. (buntika.a@chula.ac.th) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 3
PS 459-466
PD Sep 28 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Gondwanocentrus gen. nov. (type species Gondwanocentrus humphriesi sp.
   nov.) from Chile is described and illustrated. Morphological and weak
   molecular evidence indicate that the new genus may be a basal member of
   the Betylobraconini. The molecular data analysed to assess its placement
   additionally draw into question the relationship between Betylobraconini
   and Clinocentrini. Previously, the Betylobraconini were known only from
   the Australasian region, Oceania and Eocene Europe (Baltic amber), thus
   if Gondwanocentrus gen. nov. does belong to this group it confirms the
   groups present day Gondwanan distribution.
C1 Butcher, Buntika A.; Chulalongkorn Univ, Dept Biol, Phayathai Rd,
   Bangkok, 10330, Thailand, Thailand.
EM buntika.a@chula.ac.th
OI Quicke, Donald/0000-0003-4471-6775

   South America

TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Ichneumonoidea, Braconidae

TI Notes on three braconid wasps (Hymenoptera: Braconidae, Doryctinae)
   parasitizing oak long-horned beetle, Massicus raddei (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae), a severe pest of Quercus spp. in China, together with the
   description of a new species.
AU Cao, Liangming
   Yang, Zhongqi (yangzhqi@126.com) 
   Tang, Yanlong
   Wang, Xiaoyi
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 3
PS 467-474
PD Sep 28 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three species of Doryctinae (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) parasitize larvae
   of oak longhorn beetle Massicus raddei Blessig (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae), a serious wood borer pest in North China. Rhoptrocentrus
   quercusi sp. nov., is described as a new species and Doryctes petiolatus
   Shestakov, as well as Zombrus bicolor (Enderlein). The three species are
   idiobiont ectoparasitoids, and may have potential for biological control
   of oak longhorn beetle.

TI Two new species of the genus Aalatettix Zheng & Mao (Orthoptera,
   Tetrigoidea, Tetrigidae) from Taiwan, China.
AU Zheng, Fang-Qiang
   Shi, Jian-Ping
   Yin, Zhan (yinzhan@hbu.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 3
PS 482-486
PD Sep 28 2015
PY 2015
NT Individual pages paginated 486-490.
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of the genus Aalatettix Zheng & Mao, 2002, namely
   Aalatettix yangi sp. nov. and Aalatettix xiai sp. nov. are described and
   illustrated. The new species Aalatettix yangi sp. nov. is allied to
   Aalatettix gibbosa Zheng, Cao & Chen, 2011, but upper margin of pronotum
   waved in lateral view, width of frontal ridge narrower than width of
   basal joint of antennae, hind tibiae dark brown, base not pale. The new
   species Aalatettix xiai sp. nov. is allied to Aalatettix yangi sp. nov.,
   but length of pronotum shorter, not reaching epiproct, width of vertex
   1.5 times diameter of eye, lateral carinae of pronotum contracted
   backward distinctly, posterior apex of lower margin angular on lateral
   lobe of pronotum, lower margin of median femur waved, antennae placed
   under lower margin of eyes.

PM 26624147
DT Article
TI Notes on the systematic placement of Eutheia siamensis Franz
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae).
AU Jaloszynski, Pawel (scydmaenus@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4021
IS 3
PS 493-498
PD Sep 28 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Examination of the type series (holotype and single paratype) of Eutheia
   siamensis Franz (Thailand) revealed that it was composed of two
   different species, belonging not only in different genera, but also
   tribes. The holotype is a representative of Cephennomicrus Reitter
   (Cephenniini), while the paratype is a species of Paraneseuthia Franz
   (Eutheiini). Consequently, E. siamensis is redescribed as Cephennomicrus
   siamensis (Franz), comb. n.; and the paratype Paraneseuthia is
   illustrated, but the specimen is probably a female, and remains as an
   undescribed species. Cephennomicrus has already been recorded from
   Thailand, but Paraneseuthia is reported to occur in this country for the
   first time, filling a distributional gap between Far Eastern,
   Sundaland/Australian and recently discovered Himalayan and Turkish
   species of this interesting genus.
C1 Jaloszynski, Pawel; Univ Wroclaw, Museum Nat Hist, Sienkiewicza 21,
   Wroclaw, PL-50335, Poland, Poland.
EM scydmaenus@yahoo.com
OI Jaloszynski, Pawel/0000-0003-2973-1803
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Paraneseuthia [Thailand /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Scydmaenidae
OR Cephennomicrus siamensis - (Franz 1975) (Scydmaenidae): [Redescription,
   P. 494; Comb nov, Transferred from Eutheia, p. 494]. 
   Eutheia siamensis - Franz 1975 (Scydmaenidae): [Referred to,
   Cephennomicrus, p. 494]. 
   Paraneseuthia (Scydmaenidae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201004145
DT Article
TI HYDROPHYLAX BAHUVISTARA, A NEW SPECIES OF FUNGOID FROG (AMPHIBIA:
   RANIDAE) FROM PENINSULAR INDIA.
AU Padhye, Anand D.
   Jadhav, Anushree
   Modak, Nikhil
   Nameer, P.O.
   Dahanukar, Neelesh (anand.padhye@mesagc.org) 
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 7
IS 11
PS 7744-7760
PD Sep 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Hydrophylax bahuvistara, a new species of fungoid frog, is described
   from peninsular India. It can be separated from its congeners based on a
   combination of characters including wider head, outline of snout in
   dorsal view truncated, finger and toe tips without lateroventral groove,
   foot moderately webbed, metatarsals of 4th and 5th toes closely set,
   outer metatarsal tubercle small, foot length less than or equal to half
   of snout vent length, dorsal parts of shank without glandular folds and
   sparse horny spinules, and heels touch each other when the legs are
   folded at right angles to the body. Genetically, H. bahuvistara forms a
   monophyletic group with H. malabaricus as a sister clade separated by a
   raw distance of 4.0 to 4.5% in the 16s rRNA gene. Morphometrically, H.
   bahuvistara forms a significantly different cluster from H. malabaricus
   and H. gracilis in Discriminant Analysis.
C1 Dahanukar, Neelesh; Indian Inst Sci Educ & Res, G1 Block,Dr Homi Bhabha
   Rd, Pune, Maharashtra, 411008, India, India.
EM anand.padhye@mesagc.org
RI Dahanukar, Neelesh/B-2816-2012
OI Dahanukar, Neelesh/0000-0001-7162-9023; Modak,
   Nikhil/0000-0003-3303-7056
SC Zoology
SN 0974-7893; 0974-7907
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Hydrophylax bahuvistara [Goa /  / New species] [Karnataka /  / ] [Madhya
   Pradesh /  / ] [Maharashtra /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Hydrophylax - Fitzinger 1843 (Ranidae): [Key to species, P. 7755]. 
   Hydrophylax bahuvistara (Ranidae): [Sp nov, Maharashtra, P. 7748].

TI Description of a new Homidia species (Collembola: Entomobryidae) with
   labial chaetae expanded.
AU Pan, Zhixiang (pzx1118@hotmail.com) 
   Shi, Shidi
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 37
IS 3
PS 161-170
PD Sep 25 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Homidia triangulimacula sp. nov. is described from Tiantong National
   Forest Park, Zhejiang Province. It can be easily discriminated from
   other species of Homidia by triangular dark patch on dorsal central
   mesothorax, labial chaeta M replicated and labial basal and posterior
   labial chaetae expanded, 6+6 macrochaetae on posterior abdominal segment
   IV, and middle S-chaeta posterior to macrochaeta m3 on abdominal segment
   V. A detailed morphological character comparison and a key to species
   with chaetae expanded on labium or posterior labium in Homidia are
   provided here.
C1 Pan, Zhixiang; Taizhou Univ, Sch Life Sci, Taizhou, Zhejiang, 318000,
   China, China.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic note on two Lyristes cicadas (Hemiptera: Cicadidae) described
   by E. Schmidt from China.
AU Wang, Xu
   Hayashi, Masami (mh@sci.edu.saitama-u.ac.jp) 
   Wei, Cong
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 37
IS 3
PS 197-200
PD Sep 25 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The identity of two Lyristes species described by Schmidt is readdressed
   based on examination of the type materials. Lyristes wui Schmidt, 1932
   is recognized to be a junior synonym of Salvazana mirabilis Distant,
   1913, and Lyristes altaiensis Schmidt, 1932 is a junior synonym of a
   North American species, Neotibicen resh (Haldeman, 1852). Lyristes
   altaiensis may have been erroneously recorded from China most possibly
   due to the mislabeling of the holotype.
C1 Hayashi, Masami; Saitama Univ, Dept Biol, Saitama, 3388570, Japan,
   Japan.
EM mh@sci.edu.saitama-u.ac.jp

   Cicadoidea, Cicadidae
OR Lyristes jai - (Ouchi 1938) (Cicadidae): [Removal from synonymy, With
   Lyristes wui Schmidt 1932, p. 198].

   Lyristes jai (Ouchi 1938), p. 198].

   altaiensis Schmidt 1932, p. 199].
